chunks.content: Ὅτι μὲν οὖν ἐκ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ τὰ μὲν ζώων σώματα κέκραται, καὶ ὡς οὐκ ἴση πάντων ἐστὶν ἐν τῇ κράσει μοῖρα, παλαιοῖς ἀνδράσιν ἱκανῶς ἀποδέδεικται, φιλοσόφων τε καὶ ἰατρῶν τοῖς ἀρίστοις· εἴρηται δὲ καὶ πρὸς ἡμῶν ὑπὲρ αὐτῶν τὰ εἰκότα δι’ ἑτέρου γράμματος, ἐν ᾧ περὶ τῶν καθ’ Ἱπποκράτην στοιχείων ἐσκοπούμεθα. νυνὶ δὲ, ὅπερ ἐστὶν ἐφεξῆς ἐκείνῳ, τῶν κράσεων ἁπάσας ἐξευρεῖν τὰς διαφορὰς, ὁπόσαι τέ εἰσι καὶ ὁποῖαι, κατ’ εἴδη τε καὶ γένη διαιρούμενος, ἐν τῷδε τῷ γράμματι δίειμι, τὴν ἀρχὴν ἀπὸ τῆς τῶν ὀνομάτων ἐξηγήσεως ποιησάμενος. ἐπειδὰν μὲν γὰρ ἐκ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ κεκρᾶσθαι λέγωσι τὰ σώματα, τῶν ἄκρως τοιούτων ἀκούειν φασὶ χρῆναι, τοῦτ’ ἔστι τῶν στοιχείων αὐτῶν, ἀέρος, καὶ πυρὸς, καὶ ὕδατος, καὶ γῆς. ἐπειδὰν δὲ ζῶον, ἢ φυτὸν, ἢ θερμὸν, ἢ ψυχρὸν, ἢ ξηρὸν, ἢ ὑγρὸν, οὐκέθ’ ὡσαύτως. οὐδὲ γὰρ δύνασθαι ζῶον οὐδὲν οὔτ’ ἄκρως θερμὸν ὑπάρχειν, ὡς πῦρ, οὔτ’ ἄκροις ὑγρὸν, ὡς ὕδωρ· ὡσαύτως δὲ οὐδὲ ψυχρὸν ἢ ξηρὸν ἐσχάτως· ἀλλ’ ἀπὸ τοῦ πλεονεκτοῦντος ἐν τῇ κράσει γίνεσθαι τὰς προσηγορίας, ὑγρὸν μὲν καλούντων ἡμῶν, ἐν ᾧ πλείονος ὑγρότητός ἐστι μοῖρα, ξηρὸν δὲ, ἐν ᾧ ξηρότητος· οὕτω δὲ καὶ θερμὸν μὲν, ἐν ᾧ τὸ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ πλεονεκτεῖ, ψυχρὸν δὲ, ἐν ᾧ τὸ ψυχρὸν τοῦ θερμοῦ. αὕτη μὲν τῶν ὀνομάτων χρῆσις.
chunks.claude_translation:
That the bodies of living creatures are compounded from hot and cold and dry and moist, and that the portion of each in the mixture is not equal in all cases, has been adequately demonstrated by the men of old, by the best of both philosophers and physicians. And we ourselves have also stated what is reasonable concerning these matters in another work, in which we examined the elements according to Hippocrates. But now, which is the next step after that work, I shall proceed in this present work to discover all the differences of mixtures [temperaments], both how many they are and of what kind, dividing them according to species and genera, beginning with an explanation of the terms.

For whenever they say that bodies are mixed from hot and cold and dry and moist, they assert that one must understand these in their extreme form, that is, the elements themselves: air, fire, water, and earth. But whenever they speak of an animal, or a plant, as hot, or cold, or dry, or moist, it is no longer in the same way. For no animal can be extremely hot, like fire, nor extremely moist, like water; and likewise neither extremely cold nor extremely dry. Rather, the designations arise from what predominates in the mixture: we call "moist" that in which there is a greater portion of moisture, and "dry" that in which there is a greater portion of dryness; and similarly we call "hot" that in which the hot predominates over the cold, and "cold" that in which the cold predominates over the hot. This, then, is the usage of the terms.
chunks.gemini_translation:
That the bodies of living creatures are compounded, then, from the hot, the cold, the dry, and the wet, and that the share of each is not equal in the mixture [κράσει], has been sufficiently demonstrated by the ancients—by the best among both philosophers and physicians. And we ourselves have also stated what is fitting concerning these matters in another treatise, in which we examined the elements according to Hippocrates.

But now, in this present treatise, I will proceed to the next task in order: to discover all the differences among the temperaments [κράσεων]—how many and of what kind they are—dividing them according to species and genera, and I will make my start from an explanation of the terms. For whenever they say that bodies are compounded from the hot, the cold, the dry, and the wet, they mean, one must understand, these qualities in their absolute form—that is, the elements themselves: air, fire, water, and earth. But whenever they call an animal or a plant hot, or cold, or dry, or wet, it is no longer in the same sense. For it is not possible for any living creature to be absolutely hot, like fire, nor absolutely wet, like water; and likewise neither cold nor dry to the utmost degree.

But rather, the designations arise from the quality that predominates in the mixture, so that we call a thing wet in which there is a greater share of wetness, and dry in which there is a greater share of dryness; and in the same way, we call a thing hot in which the hot predominates over the cold, and cold in which the cold predominates over the hot. This, then, is the use of the terms.
chunks.openai_translation:
That the bodies of animals are composed as mixtures from the hot, the cold, the dry, and the moist, and that the share of each is not equal in the mixture [krasis: mixture/temperament], has been sufficiently demonstrated by the ancients, the best of the philosophers and physicians; and what is plausible on these matters has also been stated by us in another treatise [gramma: treatise], in which we examined the elements [stoicheia: elements] according to Hippocrates. Now, as what follows upon that, I shall in this treatise set out, by distinguishing into species and genera, all the differences of mixtures—how many they are and of what sort—beginning from an explanation of the terms.

For whenever they say that bodies are mixed from the hot and the cold and the dry and the moist, they say one must understand these as things in the extreme [akros: in the absolute sense], that is, the elements themselves—air, fire, water, and earth. But when it is a living creature or a plant, or [when something is called] hot or cold or dry or moist, it is not so in the same way. For no living creature can exist as absolutely hot as fire, nor as absolutely moist as water; likewise, neither in the ultimate degree cold nor dry. Rather, the designations [prosegoriai: appellations] arise from what predominates in the mixture: we call “moist” that in which there is a greater share of moisture, and “dry” that in which there is [more] dryness; and likewise, “hot” that in which the hot predominates over the cold, and “cold” that in which the cold [predominates] over the hot. This, then, is the usage of the terms.

chunks.content: Ὥρα δ’ ἂν εἴη λέγειν ἤδη καὶ περὶ τῶν κράσεων αὐτῶν. ἡ μὲν δὴ πλείστη δόξα τῶν ἐπιφανεστάτων ἰατρῶν τε καὶ φιλοσόφων, ὑγρὰν εἶναι καὶ θερμὴν κρᾶσιν, ἑτέραν τῆς ὑγρᾶς καὶ ψυχρᾶς, καὶ τρίτην ἐπὶ ταύταις τὴν ξηρὰν καὶ ψυχρὰν, ἑτέραν τῆς ξηρᾶς τε ἅμα καὶ θερμῆς. ἔνιοι δ’ ἐξ αὐτῶν ὑγρὰν μέν τινα καὶ ψυχρὰν ἅμα κρᾶσιν ὑπάρχειν φασὶ, θερμὴν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὰν ἑτέραν· οὐ μὴν οὔτε τὴν ὑγρὰν ἅμα καὶ θερμὴν, οὔτε τὴν ψυχρὰν ἅμα καὶ ξηράν. οὐ γὰρ ἐγχωρεῖν οὔθ’ ὑγρότητα πλεονεκτούσῃ θερμότητι συνδραμεῖν, οὔτε ξηρότητα ψυχρότητι. δαπανᾶσθαι μὲν γὰρ ὑπὸ τοῦ θερμοῦ κρατοῦντος τὴν ὑγρότητα, καὶ οὕτως θερμὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν γίνεσθαι τὸ σῶμα, μένειν δὲ ἄπεπτόν τε καὶ ἀκατέργαστον, ἐν οἶς ἂν σώμασιν ἀῤῥωστῇ τὸ θερμὸν, ὥστ’ ἀναγκαῖον εἶναι, θερμότητος μὲν ἐπικρατούσης, ἕπεσθαι ξηρότητα, ψυχρότητος δὲ πλεονεκτούσης, ἀκολουθεῖν ὑγρότητα. οὗτοι μὲν οὖν κατὰ τάδε πεπείκασι σφᾶς αὐτοὺς, ὡς δύο εἰσὶ πᾶσαι τῶν κράσεων αἱ διαφοραί. ὅσοι δὲ τέτταρας εἶναι νομίζουσι, διχῶς τούτοις ἀντιλέγουσιν· ἔνιοι μὲν εὐθὺς τὸ πρῶτον ἀξίωμα μὴ συγχωροῦντες, ὡς ἐξικμάζεσθαι τὴν ὑγρότητα πρὸς τοῦ θερμοῦ κρατοῦντος ἀναγκαῖόν ἐστιν· ἔνιοι δὲ τοῦτο μὲν συγχωροῦσιν, ἀμφισβητοῦσι δὲ ἑτέρως. οἱ μὲν δὴ πρῶτοι τοῦ θερμοῦ μὲν ἔργον εἶναί φασι τὸ θερμαίνειν, ὥσπερ καὶ τοῦ ψυχροῦ τὸ ψύχειν, τοῦ ξηροῦ δ’ αὖ τὸ ξηραίνειν, ὥσπερ καὶ τοῦ ὑγροῦ τὸ ὑγραίνειν. καὶ διὰ τοῦτο, ὅσα μὲν σώματα θερμὰ τὴν φύσιν ἐστὶν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὰ, καθάπερ τὸ πῦρ, ᾗ μὲν θερμὰ, θερμαίνει, ᾗ δὲ ξηρὰ, ξηραίνει.
chunks.claude_translation: Now it would be time to speak also about the temperaments themselves. The prevailing opinion of the most distinguished physicians and philosophers is that there is a moist and hot temperament, another that is moist and cold, and a third in addition to these that is dry and cold, and another that is both dry and hot. But some of them say that there exists a certain temperament that is both moist and cold, and another that is both hot and dry; however, neither one that is both moist and hot, nor one that is both cold and dry. For it is not possible either for moisture to accompany predominant heat, or for dryness to accompany coldness. For moisture is consumed by prevailing heat, and thus the body becomes both hot and dry; but it remains undigested and unprocessed in those bodies in which heat is weak, so that it is necessary that when heat predominates, dryness follows, and when coldness prevails, moisture follows. These people, then, have convinced themselves on these grounds that there are in all two differences of temperaments. But those who believe there are four oppose them in two ways: some by immediately not conceding the first premise, that it is necessary for moisture to be dried up by prevailing heat; while others concede this point but dispute it in another way. The first group say that the function of heat is to heat, just as that of cold is to cool, and in turn the function of dryness is to dry, just as that of moisture is to moisten. And for this reason, those bodies that are by nature both hot and dry, like fire, insofar as they are hot, heat, and insofar as they are dry, dry.
chunks.gemini_translation:
It is now time to speak about the temperaments [Greek: *kraseis*, "mixtures" or "constitutions"] themselves. Now, the most widespread opinion of the most distinguished physicians and philosophers is that there is a wet and hot temperament; another, the wet and cold; a third in addition to these, the dry and cold; and another that is at once dry and hot.

Some of them, however, say that a temperament that is at once wet and cold exists, and another that is at once hot and dry; but not one that is at once wet and hot, nor one that is at once cold and dry. For, they say, it is not possible either for moisture to combine with a prevailing heat, or for dryness with coldness. For moisture is consumed by the dominant heat, and so the body becomes at once hot and dry; but it remains undigested and unworked in whatever bodies the heat is weak, so that it is necessary, when heat is dominant, for dryness to follow, and when coldness is prevalent, for moisture to ensue. These men, therefore, have persuaded themselves on these grounds that the varieties of the temperaments are two in all.

But those who believe there are four argue against them in two ways: some, by not conceding the very first premise, namely that it is necessary for moisture to be dried out by the dominant heat; while others concede this point, but dispute it in another way. The first group, then, say that the function of the hot is to heat, just as that of the cold is to cool, and that of the dry, in turn, is to dry, just as that of the wet is to moisten. And for this reason, whatever bodies are by nature at once hot and dry, such as fire, heat insofar as they are hot, and dry insofar as they are dry.
chunks.openai_translation: Now it would be time to speak also about their mixtures [krasis: the temperament or blending of qualities]. The most prevalent opinion among the most illustrious physicians and philosophers is that there is a mixture that is moist and warm, another that is moist and cold, and, in addition to these, a third that is dry and cold, and another that is both dry and warm. Some of them, however, say that there exists a mixture that is at once moist and cold, and another that is at once warm and dry; but not one that is at once moist and warm, nor one that is at once cold and dry. For it is not possible for moisture to go together with heat when it has the upper hand, nor for dryness with cold. For moisture is consumed by the prevailing heat, and thus the body becomes at once warm and dry; whereas [the moisture] remains unconcocted and unprocessed [pepsis: physiological “concoction”/maturation] in those bodies in which the heat is weak, so that it is necessary, when heat predominates, for dryness to follow, and when cold predominates, for moisture to accompany it. These people, then, on such grounds have convinced themselves that all the differences of mixtures are two. Those who think there are four oppose them in two ways: some do not concede the initial assumption, namely that it is necessary for the moisture to be dried out by the predominating heat; others concede this but dispute in another way. The first say that heating is the function of the hot, just as cooling is that of the cold, and again drying that of the dry, as moistening is that of the moist. And for this reason, whatever bodies are by nature both hot and dry, like fire, insofar as they are hot they heat, and insofar as they are dry they dry.

chunks.content: ὅσα δ’ ὑγρὰ καὶ θερμὰ, καθάπερ ὕδωρ θερμὸν, ὑγραίνειν ταῦτα καὶ θερμαίνειν πέφυκεν ἀεὶ, ἓν ἑκατέρας κᾀνταῦθα ποιότητος ἔργον ἐχούσης ἀχώριστον. οὐκ οὖν συγχωροῦσιν, εἴ τι θερμαῖνόν ἐστιν, εὐθὺς τοῦτο καὶ ξηραίνειν· ἀλλ’ εἰ μὲν ὑγρότης προσείη τῇ θερμότητι, θερμαίνειν ἅμα καὶ ὑγραίνειν, ὥσπερ τὰ λουτρὰ τῶν γλυκέων ὑδάτων· εἰ δ’, ὥσπερ θερμὸν, οὕτω καὶ ξηρὸν εἴη, καθάπερ τὸ πῦρ, οὐ θερμαίνειν μόνον, ἀλλὰ καὶ ξηραίνειν εὐθὺς, οὐκ ἐκ τῆς θερμότητος τοῦτο λαβὸν, ἀλλ’ ἐκ τῆς συνούσης αὐτῇ ξηρότητος. ὑπομιμνήσκουσι δ’ ἐνταῦθα τῶν ἐν ἡλίῳ θερινῷ διατριψάντων ἐπιπλέον, εἶθ’, ὡς εἰκὸς, αὐανθέντων, ὅλον τε τὸ σῶμα καὶ ξηρὸν καὶ αὐχμηρὸν ἐχόντων, καὶ διψώντων οὐκ ἀνεκτῶς.
chunks.gemini_translation: ERROR: 503 UNAVAILABLE. {'error': {'code': 503, 'message': 'The model is overloaded. Please try again later.', 'status': 'UNAVAILABLE'}}
chunks.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

**Text 2.2:**

But things that are moist and hot, such as hot water, are naturally disposed always to moisten and to heat, each quality having in this case too a single inseparable function. Therefore they do not concede that if something heats, it immediately also dries; rather, if moisture is present along with the heat, it heats and moistens at the same time, just as baths of fresh water do; but if, just as it is hot, so too it is dry, like fire, it not only heats but also immediately dries, deriving this not from the heat but from the dryness that accompanies it. And here they remind us of those who have spent too much time in the summer sun and then, as is natural, have become parched, having their whole body both dry and withered, and suffering from unbearable thirst.
chunks.openai_translation: But whatever things are moist and hot, like warm water, are by nature always disposed to moisten and to heat, each of the two qualities in this case having a single, inseparable operation [i.e., causal action]. Therefore they do not allow that, if something heats, it immediately also dries; rather, if moisture is added to the heat, it both heats and moistens at the same time, as do the baths of “sweet” waters [fresh, non-saline water]. But if, just as it is hot, it is also dry, like fire, it not only heats but also immediately dries—deriving this not from its heat, but from the dryness that accompanies it [dryness = one of the primary qualities]. And here they further remind us of people who have spent time in the summer sun and then, as is likely, have been dried out, whose whole body is both dry and parched, and who suffer thirst intolerably.

chunks.content: ἴασιν γὰρ αὐτοῖς εἶναί φασιν ἑτοίμην τε καὶ ῥᾴστην, οὐκ εἰ πίοιεν μόνον, ἀλλὰ εἰ καὶ λούσαιντο θερμοῖς ὕδασι καὶ γλυκέσιν, ὡς τῆς ὑγρότητος, εἴτε μετὰ ψυχρότητος, εἴτε μετὰ θερμότητος εἴη, τὸ ἑαυτῆς δρᾷν δυναμένης, ὑγραίνειν γὰρ τὰ πλησιάζοντα. κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν λόγον φασὶ καὶ τὴν ξηρότητα ξηραίνειν ἀεί. τὸν γοῦν βοῤῥᾶν, ξηρὸν καὶ ψυχρὸν ἄνεμον τυγχάνοντα, ξηραίνειν ἅπαντα καὶ ψύχειν. καὶ τοῦτ’ εἶναι τὸ πρὸς Ὁμήρου λεγόμενον, Ὡς δ’ ὅτ’ ὀπωρινὸς βορέης νεοαρδέ’ ἀλωὴν Αἶψα ξηραίνει. Κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον καὶ τὸν τοῦ μήκωνος ὀπὸν καὶ ἄλλα μυρία φάρμακα ξηραίνειν ἅμα καὶ ψύχειν.
chunks.claude_translation: For they say that a cure is available to them that is both ready at hand and very easy, not only if they should drink, but also if they should bathe in waters that are warm and sweet, on the grounds that moisture, whether it be accompanied by coldness or by heat, is able to perform its own function—namely, to moisten things that come near it. And according to the same reasoning, they say that dryness always dries. At any rate, the north wind [Boreas], being a dry and cold wind, dries and cools everything. And this is what is said by Homer: "As when the autumn north wind quickly dries a newly watered threshing floor." And in the same manner both the juice of the poppy and countless other drugs dry and cool at the same time.
chunks.gemini_translation: For they say that a ready and very easy cure is available to them, not only if they were to drink, but also if they were to bathe in hot and fresh waters, on the grounds that wetness, whether it be with coldness or with heat, is able to perform its own function, for it moistens whatever is near. And according to the same principle, they say that dryness always dries. The north wind [Boreas], for instance, being a dry and cold wind, dries and cools everything. And this is what is said by Homer: "Just as when the autumn north wind quickly dries a newly watered threshing-floor." And in the same way, [they say that] both the juice of the poppy [ὀπός, from which opium is derived] and countless other drugs dry and cool at the same time.
chunks.openai_translation: For they say that for them a cure is both ready to hand and the easiest—not only if they should drink, but even if they should bathe in warm and fresh [i.e., non-saline] waters—since moisture, whether accompanied by cold or by heat, is able to perform its own proper action, namely to moisten what lies close by. On the same principle they say that dryness always dries. For instance, Boreas [the north wind], being a dry and cold wind, dries everything and cools it—and this is what is meant in the line from Homer: “As when the autumnal Boreas quickly dries a newly watered threshing-floor.” Likewise, in the same way the juice of the poppy [opium] and countless other drugs dry and cool at the same time.

chunks.content: ὥστ’ οὐκ ἀναγκαῖον, οὔτ’ εἴ τι ψυχρὸν, εὐθὺς τοῦτο καὶ ὑγρὸν ὑπάρχειν, οὔτ’, εἴ τι θερμὸν, εὐθὺς καὶ ξηρόν· οὔκουν οὐδὲ τὴν θερμὴν κρᾶσιν ἐξ ἀνάγκης εἶναι καὶ ξηρὰν, ἀλλὰ δύνασθαί ποτε τὸ μὲν θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ πλεονεκτεῖν ἐν τῇ κράσει τοῦ ζώου, τὸ δ’ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ. καὶ γὰρ δὴ καὶ τὴν γένεσιν, καὶ τὴν ἀλλοίωσιν, καὶ τὴν μεταβολὴν ἐκ τῶν ἐναντίων εἰς τὰ ἐναντία γίνεσθαι. τίς γὰρ οὖν εἰπὼν, ὅτι τὸ λευκὸν ἠλλοιώθη τε καὶ μετέβαλεν, ἐγένετο γὰρ θερμὸν, οὐκ ἂν εἴη καταγέλαστος; ἐπιζητεῖ γὰρ ὁ λόγος, οὐ τὴν κατὰ ψυχρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἀντίθεσιν, ἀλλὰ τὴν κατὰ τὸ χρῶμα μεταβολήν· μεταβάλλει γὰρ τὸ μὲν λευκὸν εἰς τὸ μέλαν, ὥσπερ καὶ τὸ μέλαν εἰς τὸ λευκὸν, καὶ τὸ θερμὸν αὖ εἰς τὸ ψυχρὸν, ὥσπερ καὶ τὸ ψυχρὸν εἰς τὸ θερμόν. οὕτω δὲ καὶ τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν εἰς τὸ ξηρὸν, τὸ δ’ αὖ ξηρὸν εἰς τὸ ὑγρόν. εἰ γὰρ δὴ φάσκει τις ἠλλοιῶσθαι τὸ σῶμα τῷ τέως ὑγρὸν ὑπάρχον εἶναι νῦν λευκὸν, ἢ τῷ τέως ξηρὸν ὂν τὸ νῦν φαίνεσθαι μέλαν, οὐκ ἂν ὑγιαίνειν δόξειεν. εἰ δέ γε τὸ τέως ὑγρὸν τὸ νῦν ξηρὸν φαίη γενέσθαι, ἢ τὸ πρότερον ὑπάρχον μέλαν νῦν εἶναι λευκὸν, ἢ ἐκ θερμοῦ ψυχρὸν, ἢ ἐκ ψυχροῦ θερμὸν γεγονέναι, σωφρονεῖν ἂν δόξειεν ὁ τοιοῦτος, καὶ λέγειν τὰ εἰκότα. τὸ γὰρ μεταβάλλον, ᾗ μεταβάλλει, ταύτῃ μεταχωρεῖν δεῖ πρὸς τοὐναντίον. ἐγένετο γοῦν ἢ γίγνεται μουσικὸς ὅδε, φαμὲν, ἐξ οὐ μουσικοῦ δηλονότι, καὶ γραμματικὸς ἐξ οὐ γραμματικοῦ, καὶ ῥητορικὸς ἐξ οὐ ῥητορικοῦ· τὸ δ’ ἐκ μουσικοῦ γραμματικὸν, ἢ ἐκ γραμματικοῦ μουσικὸν, ἢ ἐξ ἄλλου τινὸς τῶν ἑτερογενῶν γίνεσθαί τι λέγειν ἄτοπον. ἐγχωρεῖ γὰρ τὸν τέως γραμματικὸν νῦν μουσικὸν γεγονέναι, προσκτησάμενον τῇ γραμματικῇ τὴν μουσικὴν, οὐκ ἀποβαλόντα τὴν γραμματικήν. καὶ μὴν εἰ προσεκτήσατό τι, μένοντος τοῦ προτέρου, παντί που δῆλον, ὡς οὐκ ἠλλοιώθη κατὰ τὸ μένον. ὥστ’ οὐκ ἐκ γραμματικοῦ μουσικὸς ἐγένετο· καὶ γὰρ καὶ νῦν ἔτι γραμματικός ἐστιν· ἀλλ’ ἐξ ἀμούσου μουσικός· οὐ γὰρ ἔτ’ ἐγχωρεῖ μένειν αὐτὸν ἄμουσον, μουσικόν γε ἤδη γεγονότα. πασῶν γοῦν τῶν μεταβολῶν ὑπὸ τῶν ἐναντίων τε κᾀκ τῶν ἐναντίων εἰς τὰ ἐναντία γιγνομένων, δηλονότι καὶ τὸ ὑγρὸν, εἰ μεταβάλλει ποτὲ, καθ’ ὅσον ὑγρὸν, αὐτό τε ξηρανθήσεται καὶ τὸ ξηραῖνον αὐτὸ ξηρὸν λεχθήσεται. μὴ τοίνυν λεγόντων, φασὶν, ὡς θερμὴν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὰν κρᾶσιν οὐκ ἐγχωρεῖ γενέσθαι. θερμὴν μὲν γὰρ ἅμα καὶ ψυχρὰν εἶναι τὴν αὐτὴν, ἢ ὑγρὰν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὰν οὐκ ἐγχωρεῖ· συνυπάρχειν γὰρ ἀλλήλαις οὐχ οἷόν τε καθ’ ἓν καὶ ταὐτὸ σῶμα τὰς ἐναντίας ποιότητας· ἅμα δ’ ὑγρόν τι καὶ θερμὸν, καὶ ψυχρὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν εἶναι δυνατὸν, ὡς ὅ τε λόγος ἀπέδειξε καὶ τὰ σμικρῷ πρόσθεν εἰρημένα παραδείγματα. τοιοῦτος μὲν οὖν ὁ τῶν προτέρων λόγος.
chunks.claude_translation: Therefore it is not necessary that if something is cold, it should immediately also be moist, nor that if something is hot, it should immediately also be dry. Consequently, neither is it necessary that a hot mixture [krasis] should also be dry, but it is possible that sometimes the hot may predominate over the cold in the mixture of the living creature, while the moist predominates over the dry. For indeed generation, alteration, and change occur from contraries to contraries. For who, having said that the white has been altered and changed—for it has become hot—would not be laughable? For the argument seeks not the opposition according to cold and hot, but the change according to color. For the white changes into the black, just as the black also changes into the white, and the hot in turn into the cold, just as the cold also into the hot. And in the same way, the moist changes into the dry, and the dry in turn into the moist. For if someone should claim that the body has been altered because what was previously moist is now white, or because what was previously dry now appears black, he would not seem to be in his right mind. But if he should say that what was previously moist has now become dry, or that what was previously black is now white, or that it has become cold from hot, or hot from cold, such a person would seem to be sensible and to speak reasonably. For what changes, insofar as it changes, must in that respect move toward its opposite. At any rate, we say that this person has become or is becoming musical, clearly from being non-musical, and literate from being non-literate, and rhetorical from being non-rhetorical. But to say that something becomes literate from being musical, or musical from being grammatical, or that something comes to be from some other heterogeneous quality is absurd. For it is possible that one who was previously literate has now become musical, having acquired music in addition to literacy, not having lost literacy. And yet if he has acquired something while the former remains, it is surely clear to everyone that he has not been altered with respect to what remains. Therefore he has not become musical from being literate—for indeed he is still literate even now—but musical from being non-musical. For it is no longer possible for him to remain non-musical, having already become musical. Since, then, all changes occur by contraries, from contraries, and into contraries, clearly the moist too, if it ever changes, insofar as it is moist, will itself be dried and what dries it will be called dry. Therefore, they say, let them not say that it is impossible for a mixture to be both hot and moist at the same time. For it is impossible for the same thing to be both hot and cold at the same time, or both moist and dry at the same time; for it is not possible for contrary qualities to coexist in one and the same body. But it is possible for something to be both moist and hot at the same time, and both cold and dry at the same time, as both reason has demonstrated and the examples given a little earlier. Such, then, is the argument of the earlier thinkers.
chunks.gemini_translation:
Therefore, it is not necessary, either that if something is cold, it is immediately also wet, or that if something is hot, it is immediately also dry. Consequently, it is not necessary for a hot temperament [κρᾶσις] to be also a dry one, but it is possible at times for the hot to predominate over the cold in the temperament of a living being, and the wet over the dry. For indeed generation, alteration, and change occur from opposites and into opposites. For who, then, would not be ridiculous for saying that a white thing was altered and changed, on the grounds that it became hot? For the argument requires not the opposition between cold and hot, but the change with respect to color. For white changes into black, just as black also changes into white, and hot, in turn, into cold, just as cold also into hot. And so too the wet changes into the dry, and the dry, in turn, into the wet. For if someone were to claim that a body has been altered because, having previously been wet, it is now white, or because, being previously dry, it now appears black, he would not be thought to be of sound mind. But if he were to say that what was previously wet has now become dry, or that what was formerly black is now white, or has become cold from hot, or hot from cold, such a person would be thought to be sensible and to be saying what is reasonable. For that which changes must, in the very respect in which it changes, pass over to its opposite. For instance, we say that this man became or is becoming musical, clearly from being non-musical, and grammatical from being non-grammatical, and rhetorical from being non-rhetorical; but to say that something becomes grammatical from being musical, or musical from being grammatical, or that anything comes to be from something of a different kind, is absurd. For it is possible for one who was previously a grammarian to have now become a musician, having acquired music in addition to grammar, not by having lost his grammar. And surely, if he has acquired something while the previous state remains, it is clear to everyone, I suppose, that he has not been altered with respect to that which remains. Therefore, he did not become a musician *from* being a grammarian—for indeed he is still a grammarian now—but rather he became a musician from being unmusical; for it is no longer possible for him to remain unmusical, once he has already become a musician. Since, therefore, all changes are brought about by opposites and proceed from opposites into opposites, it is clear that the wet also, if it ever changes, insofar as it is wet, will itself be dried, and that which dries it will be called dry.

Therefore, let them not say, they [the predecessors] argue, that it is impossible for a temperament to be at once hot and wet. For it is impossible for the same thing to be at once hot and cold, or at once wet and dry, since it is not possible for opposite qualities to coexist with each other in one and the same body. But it is possible for something to be at once wet and hot, and at once cold and dry, as both the argument has demonstrated and the examples stated a little earlier.

Such, then, is the argument of our predecessors.
chunks.openai_translation:
Therefore it is not necessary that, if something is cold, it at once is also moist, nor that, if something is hot, it at once is also dry. Accordingly, a hot krasis [mixture/temperament] is not of necessity also dry; rather, it can happen that in the animal’s krasis the hot outweighs the cold, while the moist outweighs the dry. For indeed, coming-to-be [genesis], alteration [alloiōsis], and change [metabolē] occur from contraries into contraries.

For who, if he said, “the white has been altered and has changed—for it became hot,” would not be laughable? For the account in question is seeking not the opposition according to cold and hot, but the change according to color; for white passes into black, just as black into white, and hot in turn into cold, just as cold into hot. And so too the moist into the dry, and again the dry into the moist. For if someone claims that the body has been altered in that what was formerly moist is now white, or in that what was formerly dry now appears black, he would seem not to be in his right mind. But if he should say that what was formerly moist has now become dry, or that what previously existed as black is now white, or that from hot it has become cold, or from cold has become hot, such a person would seem sensible and to be speaking plausibly. For that which changes must, in the respect in which it changes, pass over toward its opposite.

At any rate, we say that this person has become or is becoming musical from being unmusical, plainly, and literate [grammatikos: trained in grammar] from being illiterate, and a rhetorician [rhetorikos] from being non-rhetorician; but to say that something becomes literate from being musical, or musical from being literate, or from some other heterogeneous thing, is absurd. For it is admissible that the one who was formerly literate has now become musical, having acquired music in addition to grammar, not having cast grammar away. And indeed, if he has acquired something while the former trait remains, it is clear to everyone that he has not been altered with respect to what remains. Accordingly, he did not become musical from being literate; for even now he is still literate. Rather, from being unmusical he is musical; for it is no longer possible for him to remain unmusical, seeing that he has already become musical.

Since all changes, at any rate, occur both by contraries and from contraries into contraries, it is evident that the moist too, if it ever changes, inasmuch as it is moist, will itself be dried out, and that that which dries it will be called dry. Therefore, let them not say, they declare, that it is impossible for a hot-and-moist krasis to come to be at the same time. For the same thing cannot be at once hot and cold, or at once moist and dry; for contrary qualities cannot co-exist in one and the same body as such. But it is possible for something to be at once moist and hot, and at once cold and dry, as both the argument has shown and the examples mentioned a little earlier. Such, then, is the account of the earlier thinkers.

chunks.content: ὁ δὲ τῶν δευτέρων οὐδὲν ἄτοπον εἶναί φησιν, ὑποκειμένου τοῦ θερμοῦ δραστικωτάτου τῶν τεττάρων, ὡς μὴ μόνον εἰς τὸ ψυχρὸν, ἀλλὰ καὶ εἰς τὸ ὑγρὸν ἐνεργεῖν, εἶναι κρᾶσιν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν, ὅταν ἐς ταὐτὸ ἅμα συνέλθῃ πλῆθος ὑγρότητός τε καὶ θερμότητος εὐθὺς ἐν τῇ πρώτῃ γενέσει τοῦ ζώου. ὁ δὲ λόγος ἐκείνων οὐχ, ὡς οὐκ ἄν ποτε γένοιτο καθ’ ἓν καὶ ταὐτὸ σῶμα τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ πλέον, τὸ δὲ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ, δείκνυσιν, ἀλλ’ ὡς οὐκ ἂν διαμείναι τοιοῦτο ἄχρι παντός· ἀεὶ γὰρ ἐξικμαζόμενον ὑπὸ τοῦ θερμοῦ τὸ ὑγρὸν ἐν τῷ χρόνῳ ξηρὸν ἀποδείξει τὸ σῶμα· καὶ οὕτως οὐκ ἂν ἔτι θερμὸν καὶ ὑγρὸν, ἀλλὰ θερμὸν εἴη καὶ ξηρόν· αὐτὸ δ’ οὖν πάλιν τοῦτο, τὸ θερμὸν καὶ ξηρὸν, ἐπὶ προήκοντι τῷ χρόνῳ ξηρὸν ἔσται καὶ ψυχρόν. ἐπειδὰν γὰρ ἐκβοσκήσηται τὴν ἰκμάδα πᾶσαν αὐτοῦ τὸ θερμὸν, ἄρχεται τοὐντεῦθεν ἤδη, φασὶ, καὶ αὐτὸ μαραίνεσθαι, μηκέτ’ εὐποροῦν τροφῆς, ὅθεν ἐξήπτετο. θαυμαστὸν οὖν οὐδὲν εἶναι νομίζουσι, καὶ κατ’ ἀρχὰς μὲν εὐθὺς ἐν τῇ πρώτῃ γενέσει τοῦ ζώου συνδραμεῖν εἰς ταὐτὸ ἢ τὸ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ πλέον, ἢ τὸ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ. δυνατὸν δὲ κᾀν τῷ χρόνῳ προϊόντι γίνεσθαι τὴν τέως θερμὴν καὶ ὑγρὰν κρᾶσιν αὖθις θερμὴν καὶ ξηρὰν, ὥσπερ γε καὶ αὖθις πάλιν τὴν ξηρὰν καὶ θερμὴν, ἀποσβεννυμένου τοῦ θερμοῦ, ψυχρὰν καὶ ξηρὰν ἀποτελεσθῆναι.
chunks.claude_translation: But the proponent of the second view says there is nothing absurd, given that the hot is the most active of the four [qualities], so that it acts not only upon the cold but also upon the moist, in there being a moist and hot mixture whenever an abundance of both moisture and heat comes together at the same time right at the first generation of the animal. But the argument of those others does not demonstrate that it could never happen that in one and the same body the moist exceeds the dry while the hot exceeds the cold, but rather that such a state could not remain so forever; for the moist, being constantly evaporated by the hot, will in time render the body dry; and thus it would no longer be hot and moist, but would be hot and dry; and then again this very thing, the hot and dry, as time advances will become dry and cold. For whenever the hot has consumed all its moisture, from that point on, they say, it too begins to wither away, no longer having an abundant supply of the nourishment from which it was kindled. Therefore they consider it not at all remarkable that both at the beginning, right at the first generation of the animal, there should come together at the same time either the moist in excess of the dry, or the hot in excess of the cold, and that it is also possible, as time progresses, for the mixture that was previously hot and moist to become in turn hot and dry, just as again in turn the dry and hot mixture, when the hot is extinguished, becomes cold and dry.
chunks.openai_translation:
But the spokesman of the second [view] says there is nothing out of the way in this, on the assumption that heat, being the most active of the four [primary qualities], acts not only upon the cold but also upon the moist: there can be a moist and hot mixture [krasis] whenever, at one and the same time, a great quantity of moisture and of heat come together straightaway in the animal’s first generation.

The reasoning of those men does not show that it could never occur in one and the same body that the moist should exceed the dry and the hot the cold, but rather that such a condition would not endure for all time; for the moist, continually being ripened/dried out by the heat, will in time render the body dry. And thus it would no longer be hot and moist, but hot and dry; and this very state again, the hot and dry, as time advances will become dry and cold. For whenever the heat has consumed [lit. “grazed off”] all its moisture [ikmada: vital moisture/sap], from that point, they say, it too begins to wither, no longer being well supplied with the nourishment from which it had been kindled.

Accordingly they think it nothing surprising that, at the outset—straightaway in the animal’s first coming-to-be—there should run together into one [subject] either an excess of the moist over the dry or of the hot over the cold. And as time goes on it is possible for the mixture that was previously hot and moist to become again hot and dry, just as, again in turn, when the heat is quenched, the dry and hot is brought to be cold and dry.
chunks.gemini_translation:
But the one who holds the second view says that there is nothing strange—on the assumption that the hot is the most active of the four qualities, so that it acts not only upon the cold but also upon the wet—in there being a wet and hot temperament [krasis], whenever an abundance of both wetness and hotness comes together at the same time, right at the first coming-to-be of the animal. But the argument of those others proves not that the wet could never be more than the dry and the hot more than the cold in one and the same body, but that such a state would not last forever. For as the wet is constantly being dried out by the hot, this will in time render the body dry; and thus it would no longer be hot and wet, but would be hot and dry. And this very state, the hot and dry, will in turn, over an extended time, become dry and cold. For whenever the hot has consumed all of its moisture [ikmas], from that point, they say, it too begins to wither away, no longer having a ready supply of the nourishment from which it was kindled.

Therefore, they think it is not at all surprising that, at the very beginning, right in the first coming-to-be of the animal, an excess of wet over dry and an excess of hot over cold should combine in the same being. And it is possible, as time goes on, for the temperament that was for a time hot and wet to become in turn hot and dry, just as, indeed, it is possible yet again for the hot and dry temperament, as its heat is extinguished, to be rendered cold and dry.

chunks.content: ὅτι μὲν οὖν ἐγχωρεῖ καὶ θερμὴν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὰν εἶναί τινα, καὶ ψυχρὰν καὶ ξηρὰν ἑτέραν τῆσδε κρᾶσιν, ἐκ τούτων ἀποδεικνύουσιν. ὅτι δὲ πλείους τῶν τεττάρων διαφορὰς κράσεων ἀδύνατον ὑπάρχειν, ἐκ τῶνδε πειρῶνται διδάσκειν.
chunks.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"That it is possible, then, for one mixture to be both hot and moist at the same time, and for another mixture different from this one to be cold and dry, they demonstrate from these considerations. But that it is impossible for there to be more than four differences of mixtures, they attempt to teach from the following arguments."
chunks.gemini_translation:
From these points, then, they demonstrate that it is possible for one mixture [krasis] to be at once hot and moist, and for another to be cold and dry; but from the following points, they attempt to teach that it is impossible for more than the four varieties of mixtures [kraseis] to exist.

[krasis / kraseis]: A mixture, blending, or temperament, referring in this context to the combination of the fundamental qualities (hot, cold, wet, dry).
chunks.openai_translation: Accordingly, that it is possible for something to be at once hot and moist, and that another mixture, different from this one, be cold and dry, they demonstrate from the following considerations. But that it is impossible for there to be more than four varieties of mixtures [krâsis: the combination or temperament of qualities], they attempt to show from what follows.

chunks.content: ὑποκειμένων γὰρ, φασὶ, τεττάρων ποιοτήτων, εἰς ἀλλήλας τε τὸ δρᾷν καὶ πάσχειν ἐχουσῶν, θερμότητός τε καὶ ψυχρότητος, καὶ ξηρότητος καὶ ὑγρότητος, ἀντιθέσεις γίνεσθαι δύο, τὴν μὲν ἑτέραν, ἐν ᾗ τὸ θερμὸν ἀντίκειται τῷ ψυχρῷ, τὴν δ’ ἑτέραν, ἐν ᾗ τὸ ξηρὸν τῷ ὑγρῷ, καὶ διὰ τοῦτο τέτταρας ἀποτελεῖσθαι τὰς πάσας συζυγίας. ἓξ μὲν γὰρ γίνεσθαι τῶν τεττάρων ἀλλήλαις ἐπιπλεκομένων τὰς συζεύξεις, ἀλλὰ τὰς δύο τούτων ἀδυνάτους ὑπάρχειν. οὔτε γὰρ ὑγρὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν, οὔτε ψυχρὸν ἅμα καὶ θερμὸν δύναται γενέσθαι σῶμα. λείπεται γοῦν τέτταρας εἶναι συζυγίας κράσεων, ὑγρὰς μὲν δύο, ξηρὰς δὲ δύο, θερμότητι καὶ ψυχρότητι διῃρημένας. ἃ μὲν οὖν οἱ χαριέστατοι τῶν πρὸ ἡμῶν ἰατρῶν τε καὶ φιλοσόφων εἰρήκασι, ταῦτά ἐστιν.
chunks.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

For they say that there being four underlying qualities, which have the power both to act upon and be acted upon by one another—heat and cold, and dryness and moisture—two oppositions arise: one in which the hot is opposed to the cold, and the other in which the dry is opposed to the moist, and because of this all the combinations amount to four. For when the four are interwoven with one another, six couplings arise, but two of these turn out to be impossible. For a body can become neither moist and dry at the same time, nor cold and hot at the same time. Therefore it remains that there are four combinations of mixtures [or: blendings]: two moist and two dry, divided by heat and cold. These, then, are the things that the most elegant of the physicians and philosophers before us have said.
chunks.openai_translation: For, they say, since there are four underlying qualities, which have the capacity to act upon and be acted upon by one another—heat and cold, and dryness and moisture—two oppositions arise: in the one, the hot is set against the cold; in the other, the dry against the moist; and for this reason the total pairings come to four. For when the four interweave with one another, six couplings result, but two of these prove impossible; for a body cannot be at once moist and dry, nor at once cold and hot. It remains, then, that there are four pairings of mixtures [kraseis], two moist and two dry, distinguished by heat and cold. Such, then, are the things that the most refined of the physicians and philosophers before our time have said.
chunks.gemini_translation: For they say that, given four underlying qualities—hotness and coldness, and dryness and wetness—which are able to act and be acted upon by one another, two oppositions arise: the one, in which the hot is opposed to the cold, and the other, in which the dry is opposed to the wet; and that for this reason, four total combinations [Greek: *syzygiai*, pairings] are formed. For while six couplings arise from the four being interwoven with one another, two of these are impossible. For a body cannot become at once wet and dry, nor at once cold and hot. It remains, therefore, that there are four combinations of mixtures [Greek: *kraseis*, temperaments]: two wet and two dry, distinguished by hotness and coldness. This, then, is what the most accomplished of the physicians and philosophers before us have said.

chunks.content: ἃ δ’ ἐγὼ παραλιπεῖν αὐτοὺς νομίζω, λέγειν ἤδη καιρός.
chunks.claude_translation: "But now is the time to speak about the things which I think they have omitted."
chunks.openai_translation: But as for the things I think they have omitted, it is already the proper time to speak [of them].
chunks.gemini_translation: But the things which I believe they have omitted, it is now the time to say.
